repnme.cdata!:
Azerbaijan - Greater Baku Water Supply
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Greater Baku Water
            Supply Rehabilitation Project for Azerbaijan were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk
            to development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance
            was moderately satisfactory, and the borrower performance
            was moderately satisfactory. Lessons learned from the
            project: Assumptions used in projecting future performance
            need to be as realistic as possible, and to take due
            consideration of prevailing political, economic, and social
            risks. Development outcomes of investment projects can be
            enhanced when done in parallel with a strong overall policy
            dialogue. Technical Assistance for implementation of reform
            components should be packaged separately from consultancy
            services for investment operations. Technical Assistance
            alone cannot bring about reforms unless it is combined with
            strong political support and the commitment of all
            stakeholders, including utility management. The objectives
            and design of project sub-components should be consistent
            with the resources allocated to them. The focus on
            monitoring and evaluation during project
            implementation/supervision needs to be improved.

repnme.cdata!:
Azerbaijan - Greater Baku Water Supply
            Rehabilitation Project (Supplemental Credit) : environmental
            management plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The potential adverse, environmental
            effects resulting from the implementation of the Greater
            Baku Water Supply Rehabilitation Project, and proposed
            mitigating measures, are addressed in this environmental
            management plan, which updates the environmental assessment
            prepared for the ongoing project, but focuses on the
            activities to be financed by the Supplemental Credit, as
            follows. Construction will generate air pollution, oil and
            fuel leakage, spoil, and construction debris: aboveground
            storage tanks, and drums will be stored on low permeably
            bases to contain oil spills; excavated spoil will be stored
            at selected sites, and should be covered to minimize dust
            emissions. Impacts on flora, and fauna may endanger
            ecological interest areas: to control soil erosion,
            construction sites will be stabilized by reseeding grass
            areas, while areas along coastal stream banks should be
            avoided, to stabilize soils, and provide wildlife habitats;
            hunting will be strictly forbidden. Civil works,
            particularly in urban areas, will disturb traffic: safety
            measures will be adopted, and traffic shall be rerouted as
            necessary, in the vicinity of construction areas, in
            accordance with international practices, enforced by local
            regulations. Cultural, and archaeological heritage sites
            shall be avoided, based on a preliminary survey, to be
            conducted by the archaeology, and antiquities institutes,
            while works should be monitored if unexpected archaeological
            sites are discovered.

18156467.projn:
AZ-Greater Baku Water Supply Rehabilitation
            Project -- P008288
18156467.admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia
18156467.theme: Urban services and housing for the poor

repnme.cdata!:
Azerbaijan - Greater Baku Water Supply
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The primary objectives of the Greater
            Baku Water Supply Rehabilitation Project are to: 1) make
            emergency short term improvements in the water supply system
            to restore the water supply to Baku, in particular to the
            poorer elements of the population; 2) improve the water
            supply system as a whole; and 3) provide the basis for
            longer term planning and recovery. The project will comprise
            five major components: 1) water demand management to
            conserve water at the household level through a program of
            consumer awareness initiatives, through repairs to in-home
            plumbing, valves, taps and other fittings, and by
            rationalizing water use through meter installations and the
            implementation of a progressive water tariff; 2) operations
            and maintenance improvements to increase the amount of water
            available from the distribution system through a program of
            leak detection and repair, workshop and equipment
            acquisition, and at least a one year inventory of selected
            replacement valves and pipes; 3) supply improvements to
            improve the quantity and quality of water from the treatment
            works and enhancing the reliability of the distribution
            network ; 4) institutional capacity building to reorganize
            the water utility into a joint stock company; consolidating
            its offices; purchasing and installing new computers with
            new software; and developing training programs; and 5)
            preparation and implementation of a national policy
            framework for the water sector and preparing a regional
            master plan.
